title: The Unprecedented Quant Boom in India
excerpt: Interns in top Indian quant firms are earning $14,000 per month as global HFT giants move in. Discover why India is becoming the next hub for systematic trading.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Interns in top quant finance firms in India are already earning over 14,000 USD per month, which is roughly ₹1.23 million. These compensation levels—once seen only in global trading hubs like New York, London, or Singapore—demonstrate how aggressively the industry is growing within India.

Quant finance in India is experiencing its biggest boom yet, with opportunities that are truly unprecedented. The ecosystem is expanding rapidly: markets are deeper, liquidity is stronger, and data availability has reached new highs. Post-COVID, millions of new traders have entered the Indian markets, creating richer microstructure dynamics and opening up fresh avenues for alpha generation. With volatility and participation at all-time highs, systematic strategies and HFT models have more room to thrive than ever before.
Global HFT Expansion

Global HFT firms such as Jump Trading, Optiver, Tower Research, Jane Street, and Griffin are rapidly expanding their operations in India. These firms are no longer treating India as a low-cost engineering destination—they are building complete trading stacks within the country, including research teams, quant strategy groups, and fully operational trading desks. Infrastructure investments in colocation, networking, and data pipelines signal a long-term commitment to the Indian market.

By 2026, India is projected to become a legitimate global hub for systematic and high-frequency trading—one where meaningful alpha is discovered and executed locally. The combination of strong technical talent, world-class engineering capabilities, and deepening financial markets gives India a unique competitive advantage. As more global capital flows into Indian exchanges, the demand for skilled quants, traders, and low-latency engineers will continue to grow. For individuals looking to build careers in the Indian markets, the next decade offers extraordinary upward mobility and a rare chance to be part of a once-in-a-generation financial transformation.

title: The Inspiring Story of Bjarne Stroustrup: The Inventor of C++
excerpt: From a working-class family in Denmark to the inventor of the world's most critical high-performance language. Explore the journey of Bjarne Stroustrup.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Bjarne Stroustrup grew up in a working-class family in Aarhus, Denmark, where curiosity and learning were his main tools. He learned early that the best way to solve a problem was to understand it deeply.
Academic Foundation

● Studied Mathematics and Computer Science at Aarhus University
● Earned a PhD in Computer Science at Cambridge, focusing on efficient systems
● Joined Bell Labs, working alongside some of the smartest minds in technology
The Birth of C++

At Bell Labs he faced a problem. The programming languages of the time were either too slow or too restrictive. He needed something fast, flexible, and safe. No existing language could meet these requirements.

● Started a side project called 'C with Classes'
● Added structure, safety, and abstraction on top of C
● Focused on real-world performance and practical use
● That project became C++
● Developers around the world quickly adopted it
C++ became one of the most important programming languages in the world. It is used in finance, operating systems, gaming engines, browsers, databases, robotics, and many high-performance systems.
Global Impact

● Wrote books that taught millions programming in C++
● Helped create and shape the ISO C++ standard
● Received the Draper Prize, the Faraday Medal, and other global honors
● Became a professor at Columbia University, continuing to improve the language
● Proved that solving a practical problem can have a global impact

title: Ed Thorp: The Man Who Invented Quant Trading
excerpt: Math prodigy, card counter, and hedge fund founder. Meet Ed Thorp, the original creator of quantitative finance.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Ed Thorp: The man who invented Quant Trading and Card Counting

● Math Prodigy, earning a PhD in Mathematics from UCLA
● Mathematics professor who used probability to break blackjack
● Created the first wearable computer to beat roulette
● Founded Princeton Newport, the first true quant hedge fund
● Achieved decades of consistent outperformance with math
● Pioneered modern derivatives pricing and statistical arbitrage
● Quietly became a billionaire through discipline and science
● The original creator of quantitative finance

title: Jim Simons: The Genius Who Revolutionized Finance
excerpt: A look at the life of the world's smartest billionaire—from academic excellence in Topology to the massive success of RenTech.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Jim Simons had the life everyone dreams of having:

● Absolute genius, earning a PhD in Mathematics at University of California, Berkeley on Topology and Manifolds
● Professor of Mathematics
● Founded RenTech and revolutionized Quant Finance
● Made billions through RenTech
● Gave over $4 billion away for Research, Health, and Education
● Legend in Finance and Academia
● Named 'world's smartest billionaire'
● Loving wife and kids

title: The Quant Dream Just Went Global
excerpt: Y-Intercept raises $1.7 billion for its first external fund. High-tier quant opportunities are no longer tied to just New York and London.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Y-Intercept, a quantitative hedge fund backed by Schonfeld Strategic Advisors, raised $1.7 billion for its first external fund. That’s one of the largest hedge fund raises in Asia in recent years.
Investors include Blackstone, Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, Morgan Stanley’s fund-of-funds, plus sovereign wealth funds and pension plans from Asia, the Middle East, and North America.
Why Talent Matters More Than Location
For a long time, top quant roles were concentrated in New York, London, and Chicago. Now that is changing. Y-Intercept runs statistical arbitrage and macro strategies... right in Hong Kong.

If you are in Asia, the Middle East, South Africa, or anywhere outside traditional hubs, this is a huge opportunity. Firms are expanding globally. Competition for talent is rising; salaries and career options improve.
Raising the Bar

But Y-Intercept didn’t raise $1.7 billion just by being in the right city. They earned it through: A proven track record, deep expertise from top banks, institutional-grade execution, and strong backing. The bar for entering top quant firms hasn’t dropped. If anything, it has risen.

title: The Trap of Comparison: Measuring Your Own Growth
excerpt: Why does a founder doing $1M ARR feel behind? Learn why comparing your path to others is a losing game.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: I recently spoke with a 20 year old founder of a startup doing 1 million ARR. He told me: I feel behind. A few years ago this would have been an incredible achievement for anyone.
Look at Your Own Path
But this is how comparison works. No matter where you are, there will always be someone ahead of you. Why punish yourself by comparing your life to people with completely different situations?

Take a step back and look at your own path. Look at who you were one year ago. How much have you grown since then? Growth is not linear. It is not always loud. And it is not only measured in money or clear numbers.

title: The Story of Jane Street: Turning Rigor into Legend
excerpt: From ETF market makers to global powerhouses using OCaml. The history and culture of one of the world's top quant firms.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: The Story of Jane Street → The trading firm that became a legend. Most people don’t know how it started.

● Early years → Founded in 2000 in New York by four friends. They focused on ETFs when few others paid attention.
● Culture → Interviews centered on logic, math, and problem solving instead of financial jargon.
● Growth → Today, Jane Street trades trillions across equities, bonds, ETFs, options, and crypto.
● Philosophy → Built on collaboration and intellectual honesty. Teamwork mattered more than hierarchy.
● Global reach → Expanded to London, Hong Kong, and Amsterdam.
● Technology → Stood out for using OCaml to power its trading systems. This gave them strong advantages in reliability.
● Legacy → Jane Street defined the model of a modern quant trading firm.
A Culture of Excellence
Jane Street proved that finance can be built on math, technology, and a culture of collaboration. Its story continues to inspire me, and I aim to follow in that pursuit of excellence.

title: Cracks in the AI Bubble: Valuations vs. Reality
excerpt: Investors are nervous as AI financials fail to add up. With massive losses at OpenAI and no productivity gains reported, is the bubble bursting?
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: The AI bubble is showing cracks, Cloudflare strikes and Gemini 3 released even though Google warns.

Investors are nervous. AI stocks like NVIDIA and Microsoft pushed the S&P 500 to record highs, but the financials are not adding up. OpenAI plans to spend $1.4 trillion over the next eight years. Losses could hit $74 billion by 2028. Meanwhile, 95% of companies using generative AI report no measurable productivity gains.
Market Warnings

Stocks for Palantir, NVIDIA, and Meta have already slipped. Oracle's stock fell sharply, investors fear they’ve bet the company on one client. Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai called out 'irrationality' in the AI market. Valuations are driven by hype, not profits. If confidence drops further, a severe correction could follow.

title: Optimizing Workflow at 18: Quant Finance, ML, and Math
excerpt: A deep dive into the terminal, IDE, and mathematics resources I use to master quantitative finance and machine learning.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: I’ve optimized my workflow for coding and learning as an 18-year-old focused on Quant Finance, ML, and Mathematics. Here’s what works for me so far:

1. Terminal: Gnome Terminal + Starship with Gruvbox Rainbow makes coding fast and visually clean.
2. IDE: Neovim with NVChad (material-deep-ocean) is my go-to for coding, while VSCode handles ML projects.
3. Setup: Windows + Ubuntu WSL gives me the best of both worlds.
4. Mathematics: Overleaf + Beamer helps me create clean presentations. I’m learning calculus (Paul’s Online Math Notes), linear algebra (Interactive Linear Algebra), and statistics (All of Statistics). Soon, I’ll dive into advanced set theory.
5. Programming: C++ is my main language for speed, Python handles ML experiments, and JavaScript for visualization.
I’ll share updates as I progress over the next two months! Feel free to comment any suggestions!

title: Lessons from 100+ Quant Professionals
excerpt: Project quality, hard work, underlying ideas, and mental math. The core advice repeated by successful quants in the field.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: I have spoken to 100+ professionals in Quant Finance and here are a few things that come up again and again:
1. Quality Over Quantity
It is better to have one strong project that shows focused skills (real option prediction with ML, good Python/C++, market data, SQL) instead of ten small common projects.
2. Work Really Hard
The people who made it put in a huge amount of work. Do the advanced math, read Bloomberg, learn about firms, and keep improving.
3. Underlying Ideas and Mental Math

Don’t only learn how something works, learn *why* it works. Explain the math clearly. Also, don’t slack on arithmetic, mental math, and DSA. These are important in interviews to test problem solving and fast thinking.

title: Save Hours of Research: The AI Bubble Explained Simply
excerpt: Artificial intelligence has driven stock markets to record highs, but investors are worried. Is the AI boom the next dot-com bubble?
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Artificial intelligence has driven stock markets to record highs in 2025. Companies like Nvidia, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, and Tesla are responsible for most of the gains. The S&P 500’s 15 percent rise this year is largely due to them.

Investors are worried the AI boom may be a bubble. Stock prices are rising faster than the companies’ profits. Many AI companies are spending massive amounts on data centers and computing infrastructure while revenue remains small. OpenAI plans to spend 1.4 trillion dollars over eight years but earns only about 20 billion dollars annually. Losses are projected to grow to 74 billion dollars by 2028.
Comparisons to Dot-Com

Some analysts compare the situation to the dot-com bubble of the late 1990s. Unlike that era, today’s AI companies mostly have profits and revenue, and valuations are not as extreme. Still, the concentration of market gains in a few companies creates risk. If investor confidence drops, stock prices could fall sharply.

Global markets have already reacted. AI-related stocks fell in the US, Asia, and Europe. Nasdaq and S&P 500 experienced the largest one-day drops in nearly a month. Palantir, Nvidia, Meta, and other AI companies saw declines despite strong earnings reports. Analysts warn a correction could happen in the next months or years.
Storytelling vs. Reality

The AI industry relies heavily on storytelling and hype. Companies present AI as transformative and inevitable. They promise massive improvements in productivity and economic growth, but evidence so far is limited. Most businesses adopting generative AI see little measurable benefit. OpenAI and other leading firms have complex deals and high infrastructure spending that may not be sustainable.

Even successful AI products like ChatGPT currently lose money on every use. The infrastructure and computing costs are enormous, and companies will need consistent revenue growth to sustain spending. Current market valuations reflect investor expectations and hype more than actual profitability or productivity gains.

If the AI bubble bursts, the impact could be severe. Concentrated losses in AI stocks would affect retirement funds, investments, and employment. Indirect effects could include trillions of lost investment dollars, job losses, and economic disruption.

At the same time, the AI boom supports parts of the US economy through infrastructure spending. However, most consumer prices and economic conditions outside AI investments are unaffected. Many non-AI businesses struggle to adopt the technology, and 95 percent of companies using generative AI see no measurable productivity improvement.
AI is a real technology with potential. The current market boom, however, carries high risk. Stock valuations are driven by hype and massive spending, not guaranteed profits or productivity gains.

title: I’m the First 18-Year-Old Making 1 Million Annually
excerpt: It's not about the money; it's about the opportunities. Why I am choosing to live life to the fullest rather than being boxed in.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text:
1 million hopes and dreams.
1 million rejections from big CEOs.
1 million doubts about my future.

But the one I’m most excited about:
1 million opportunities I get to take on.
And I’m taking on every single one of them. The voice I’ve built has defined my path. 'Study hard. Quant Research. No other option.'
Choose Life
That’s not me. I’ll take on every opportunity that comes my way, and live life to its fullest. You only live once. Don’t waste it. No matter your age.

title: The Story of Two Sigma: Driven by Data and Engineering
excerpt: Founded in 2001, Two Sigma revolutionized finance through machine learning and distributed computing. Discover their approach to systematic research.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Two Sigma was founded in 2001 by David Siegel and John Overdeck in New York. Both came from backgrounds in computer science and quantitative research.
Consistent Edges through Data

The idea was clear: use advanced data analysis and machine learning to find small, consistent trading edges. The firm built a research culture where engineers, quants, and scientists worked together on problems from markets to natural language processing.
Two Sigma focused on clean data, scalable infrastructure, and disciplined experimentation. Every idea was tested, measured, and validated before capital was deployed.
Expansion and Scale

As technology advanced, Two Sigma expanded into new areas such as private investments, insurance analytics, and venture capital. The firm also became known for attracting top technical talent from academia and industry, emphasizing intellectual honesty and precision.

Today, Two Sigma manages over $60 billion across hedge fund, venture, and insurance strategies. It stands as a leading example of how data science and systematic research can power long-term success in finance.

title: LinkedIn is Full of Fake Quants: A Reality Check
excerpt: Hard work and math talent trump social media hype. Let's talk about the real path to quantitative finance.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: LinkedIn is full of fake 'Quants'. People who choose social media and influence over actual success. The only real path to Quantitative Finance is hard work, mathematical talent, and serious mental and academic discipline.
Search for Substance
What is the best resource or person actually worth looking into when starting out?

title: Oracle: Revenue Growth vs. Profitability Margins
excerpt: Oracle's cloud margins fell short, causing a 7% stock slide. Learn why revenue growth means little if gross profit doesn't follow.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Oracle set unrealistic return expectations and are seeing the consequences. Oracle’s stock fell more than 7% after reports showed its cloud margins were far lower than expected. The company earned about $900 million from renting Nvidia-powered servers last quarter but only made around $125 million in gross profit. In some cases, it even lost money on smaller GPU rentals.

This exposed a gap between growth projections and real profitability. Oracle’s earlier forecast of a 700% increase in cloud revenue over the next three years pushed investor expectations too high. When numbers didn’t match those expectations, the market adjusted.
The Takeaways

● Revenue growth means little if margins fall.
● Overstating targets can hurt credibility.
● Markets value consistency and real returns over aggressive forecasts.

Oracle’s overall gross margin dropped to 67.3%, its lowest in over a year. The company is still expanding its AI and cloud capacity, but investors will now look more closely at whether that growth is profitable.

title: My Journey's End Goal: A Space for the New Generation
excerpt: Quant finance is awesome, but it's often exclusive to PhDs. I'm building a space where voices are heard and models are built earlier.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Throughout my journey, the question I have wrestled with the most is: What is the end goal? Why am I doing this? Why does this matter? I believe I finally have it.
Quant Finance is global. Quant Finance is awesome. Most don't really hear about it before they turn 20 or 21, maybe not even until they reach PhD level. I want to change that.
Building the Pipeline

I am working to create a space where quant voices are heard. Pipelines are built. Larger institutions take the lead. The new generation of quants is here. They want to learn the math. Build the models. They just need a space where they can connect, communicate, and learn. That's the mission. Make it known.

title: The Story of SIG: Probability, Risk, and Poker
excerpt: Founded in 1987 with $30k, SIG applied game theory to options trading at a global scale. Discover the firm built on poker discipline.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: SIG was founded in 1987 by Jeff Yass and four college friends in Philadelphia. They each put in $30,000 to start trading options. The founders played poker seriously and applied the same logic to trading: probability, expected value, and risk control.
Growth through Logic

SIG became known for options market making, where math skills and quick decisions made the difference. Through the 1990s and 2000s, SIG expanded into equities, ETFs, commodities, and fixed income. The firm also grew internationally, opening offices in Dublin, Sydney, and Shanghai.

New hires were taught probability, statistics, and game theory, with poker used as a teaching tool to sharpen decision-making. SIG invested heavily in trading systems and data infrastructure to improve speed and precision.

Today, SIG is one of the largest privately held trading firms in the world. It trades tens of thousands of products every day across global markets. SIG showed how probability and mathematics could be applied directly to markets at scale.

title: Quantitative Finance is Hard: Disclosing the Truth
excerpt: Forget the bootcamps. Landing a quant job takes math excellence, a degree, and specialized skills. Here is what they don't tell you.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Quantitative Finance is hard. Landing a Quant Job is even harder. Here are a few things about Quant Finance that most don’t publicly disclose:
1. You Need a Degree

As this field becomes more popular, there will be an influx of 'Quant Bootcamps' promising six to seven-figure salaries in months. This is unfortunately not the case. Without a degree, the advanced knowledge required will not be accessible, and landing a job will be unrealistic.
2. Clearing up the Roles

Saying you are 'a quant' means very little without specifying the type:
● Quant Trader: The full-stack trader refining strategies.
● Quant Researcher: The 'true' quant, searching for 1% compounding edge through pure math.
● Quant Dev: Coding implementation and machine learning subfields.
● Risk Quant: Hedging exposure and mitigating alpha loss.
What It Actually Takes
A quant is a dedicated, lifelong learner, a skillful coder, and a fast thinker passionate about both math and finance. Let's uphold the standard.

title: Coding a Conceptual Mean Reversion Strategy in C++
excerpt: A deep dive into how I built a rolling statistics backtester at 18 using signal logic and z-scores.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: I coded a conceptual mean reversion strategy in C++ at 18. Mean reversion is a basic idea in quantitative finance: prices move around an average, and deviations create opportunities.
Technical Structure

The program uses a rolling window of recent prices to compute:
● Mean & Standard Deviation
● Z-score (measuring deviation distance)
Signal Logic

● Z-score above threshold → Short
● Z-score below threshold → Long
● Z-score close to zero → Exit

Building this helped me connect rolling statistics, signal logic, and backtesting performance measurement. Conceptual projects like this provide a foundation for pairs trading and automated execution.

title: The Story of Citadel: From Dorm Room to Global Powerhouse
excerpt: Founded in 1990 at age 22, Citadel survived the 2008 crisis to become one of the most powerful firms in finance history.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Citadel was founded in 1990 by Ken Griffin. He began trading convertible bonds from his Harvard dorm room in the late 1980s, installing a satellite dish for real-time market data.
Early Growth and Survival

With $4.6 million in seed capital, Griffin launched Citadel at age 22. Citadel suffered heavy losses during the 2008 financial crisis but recovered within a few years, rebuilding its capital and reputation.
Market-Making Dominance
Launched in 2002, Citadel Securities became one of the largest market makers in the world, executing a significant share of US retail equity trades by the 2020s.
The firm invests heavily in technology and global offices. Citadel became a model of resilience and scale in finance, combining hedge fund investing with market-making dominance.

title: The Most Successful Hedge Fund Ever Recorded: The Story of Renaissance Technologies
excerpt: Medallion generated 66% annual returns for decades. Explore how pure mathematics and data-driven research came to dominate the financial markets.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Renaissance Technologies LLC was founded in 1982 by mathematician Jim Simons after leaving academia. The firm began with a mix of discretionary and systematic strategies, but by the late 1980s, Simons shifted fully to a quantitative, model-driven approach.
The Medallion Fund

Launched in 1988, the Medallion Fund became the centerpiece of Renaissance. It was run exclusively with mathematical and statistical models. From 1988 to 2018, Medallion generated average annual returns of around 66 percent before fees and 39 percent after fees. No other hedge fund has matched this sustained performance.

Since the 1990s, the fund has been closed to outside investors. Participation is limited to employees of Renaissance, creating one of the most exclusive investment vehicles in history. Renaissance is known for using advanced mathematics, statistics, and computer models to detect patterns in market data. The firm employs scientists from diverse fields such as mathematics, physics, and computer science.
Scale and Legacy

While Medallion remained employee-only, Renaissance expanded into funds open to outside investors, such as RIEF and RIFF. These did not match Medallion’s performance. Renaissance Technologies showed how pure mathematics and data-driven research could dominate financial markets. Medallion remains the most successful hedge fund ever recorded. It is a firm that proved the power of mathematics and computing in finance.

title: The Story of DRW: From Trading Pit to Global Powerhouse
excerpt: How Don Wilson turned a small Chicago prop shop into a $10B leader in systematic trading and cryptocurrency.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: DRW was founded by Don Wilson in 1992 at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. It started with Eurodollar options trading and grew into a global proprietary trading firm focusing on quantitative modeling, technology, and market analysis.
Global Expansion and Strategic Growth

DRW has offices in Chicago, New York, London, Singapore, Tel Aviv, and beyond. They expanded through strategic acquisitions, including portfolios from Lehman Brothers in 2008 and Chopper Trading in 2015.
Cryptocurrency and Blockchain

DRW entered crypto markets early, spinning out Digital Asset Holdings. Cumberland, its crypto arm, has handled hundreds of millions in digital assets. DRW faced scrutiny from the CFTC in 2013, but the case was dismissed in 2018, confirming its trading practices.
What It Teaches

DRW shows the value of combining data, technology, and human insight. It highlights disciplined risk management, strategic growth through acquisitions, and the need to innovate early. Systematic thinking and investment in talent can turn a small operation into a global powerhouse.

title: The Legendary Jim Simons: The Man Who Solved the Market
excerpt: Mathematician, codebreaker, fund manager, and philanthropist. A look at the cut-across life of the world's most successful investor.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Born in 1938, Jim Simons pursued mathematics, earning his PhD by 23 and contributing to geometry with the Chern–Simons theory. He worked as a codebreaker during the Cold War but was fired for speaking out against the Vietnam War.
Transition to Finance

In his late 40s, with no formal economics background, he started Renaissance Technologies. The resulting Medallion Fund achieved annualized returns no other fund has matched. Alongside his wife Marilyn, he created the Simons Foundation, donating billions to education and scientific research.

His life cut across pure mathematics, finance, and philanthropy. Each field was transformed by his curiosity and persistence. He was a mathematician who became the most successful investor of all time, and then one of the greatest supporters of science. His legacy continues to inspire me, and I aspire to reach his heights.

title: Beating the Market: Lessons from the Legacy of Jim Simons
excerpt: Fundamental mastery, hard work, and accepting unpredictability—core pillars for any aspiring quant.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Had a coffee chat with the legendary Jim Simons today (in spirit). Here’s what his legacy taught me about beating the market:
Core Principles

》Work really, really hard. Achieving what he did with RenTech didn’t come from hours of doomscrolling.
》Master the fundamentals. Black, Scholes, and Merton combined stochastic calculus with logarithmic and numerical reasoning.
》Accept unpredictability. A quant’s edge is using uncertainty to their advantage.
》Stay true to your values. Work hard, but grow in all areas of life, including family.
These are real lessons I’ve learned from real mentors through his legacy. Dr. Simons may not have said them to me directly, but his impact remains a guiding light.

title: Passion is Not Enough: The Reality of University Mathematics
excerpt: From straight As to 72% in university math. My journey through the grind of higher education at Stellenbosch.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Just because I am an aspiring quant does not mean I am a genius. I discovered my love for mathematics about two years ago through computer science, which helped me visualize problems clearly. I was solid at math in school, scoring 100% on papers after hard work.
The University Reality Check

I was provisionally accepted for BCom Mathematical Sciences at Stellenbosch University. However, university mathematics is very different. Geometry didn't click and my trig wasn't sharp enough, leading to a 72% in my term 2 exams. That is tough for someone who lives and breathes quant finance.

Passion alone is not enough. Believing in yourself matters, but you still need to grind. Hard work pays off, and this term I locked in, completing every past paper possible. Some are more talented, but the path is open to those who put in the work.

title: Johannes Meyer: Beyond the World of Quant Finance
excerpt: Violins, cricket, and a late-blooming love for math. Getting to know the guy behind the quant posts.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: 15,500 followers in 6 months at 18. This is who I am beyond Quant Finance:
Cricket and Violin
Most people know me as the guy married to cricket, though hypermobility turned that into a passion rather than a career. I also play the violin—Praeludium and Allegro is my current goal.
Identity and Values

I didn't love math growing up; computer science was the bridge. I believe balance is key; one pursuit shouldn't define your entire identity. Also, monetizing things doesn't feel natural to me—I struggle with asking for money in exchange for service. Social media has walls, and people aren't always who they say they are. Keep pushing beyond the images.

title: The Landscape of Quant Finance: Know Your Firms
excerpt: From Prop Shops to Asset Managers—discover the different environments where quants thrive.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Want to break into Quant Finance? These are the types of firms you should know!
The Major Players

● Investment Banks: Manage risk and pricing derivatives (GS, JPM).
● Hedge Funds: Alpha generation and systematic research (RenTech, Citadel).
● Prop Trading Firms: Trade own capital with systematic strategies (Jane Street, Optiver).
● Asset Managers: Manage client portfolios (BlackRock, Vanguard).
● Exchanges & FinTechs: Focused on liquidity and execution innovation.
Each type offers different opportunities, from high-speed proprietary trading to long-term academic research in asset management.

title: Hello to the 13,000: My Journey Into Quant Finance
excerpt: From social media failure to 5 job offers at 18. The story behind the traction and the passion.
author: Johannes Meyer

content.text: Quant Finance is usually discovered at 20. I am 18 and already passionate about it! I discovered this world through comedic videos that sparked my curiosity. I've failed at social media 10 times before, but consistency finally gave me traction.
Momentum and Profile

Some don't know my age, resulting in 5 job offers from recruiters unaware I'm not a professional yet. I believe in balance: study hard, play cricket hard, and most importantly, rest hard. All credit to peers like Rich Zou for inspiring me to create on LinkedIn.
